Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Across the nation, community and technical colleges offer many programs and degrees in computer networking (CN) to serve business and industry, but companies are increasingly requiring a baccalaureate degree for advanced positions. To address this need, this project at Renton Technical College (RTC) is designed to create a transferable Associate of Applied Science (AAS) degree option in the Computer Network Technology (CNT) program that will facilitate the transition of students into an industry-driven Bachelor of Applied Science (BAS) degree in Computer Network Architecture to provide the education required for these advanced positions. Through enhanced partnerships with industry, it will address the annual shortage of educated professionals in the high-demand, high-paying field of CN in the service area of the college, the majority of which require a baccalaureate degree. The college will also develop articulation agreements with area high schools to help high school students transition seamlessly into the associate degree program. The project will also recruit and retain a more diverse student as it engages with local and national groups to get advice on increasing diversity in CN programs to increase the enrollment of underserved populations, women, and veterans in these programs.

By adopting the Business and Industry Leadership Team (BILT) best practice process and curricular resources created and refined by the ATE-funded National Convergence Technology Center (CTC) (DUE 1205077), the college will ensure that its AAS and BAS degrees provide students with the latest skills and knowledge they need to gain employment in the high-demand computer network field. The project will engage local employers, students, colleges, and high schools to develop a clear and achievable plan to upgrade the AAS, create a BAS, and develop articulated pathways from high school into CN programs that build on the experiences of other ATE-funded colleges. Activities will include curriculum and course development for two degrees, in-depth consultations with industry, extensive outreach to high school and college students and instructors, professional development for 20 area high school teachers, navigation of the approval processes, and creation of the infrastructure for the BAS program. The project will deeply engage employers to improve learning outcomes at the AAS level and build a BAS degree that will directly meet their need for baccalaureate level education in CN occupations. The college will collaborate with other institutions, including the Green River College ATE-funded project Expanding Career and Educational Learning in Information Technology (DUE 1400688) and other peer colleges in the National CTC's Convergence College Network (CCN) to benefit from their experiences and speed up the adoption of processes and relevant curriculum. The leadership team will share materials and findings with others in the Washington community and technical college system and with the CCN members through presentations, publications and listservs to help others in building similar programs around the country. It will also reach out to other programs at RTC to share the BILT process and help increase partnerships with industry. Evaluation of the project will include both formative and summative elements to help ensure the project team's work with the BILT and student experiences are positive and productive.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Next Level Networking (NLN) Project's mission is to advance technical education in the Pacific Northwest. It achieved this by developing a transferable Associate of Applied Science (AAS-T) degree option in the Computer Network Technology (CNT) program that facilitated the transition of students into an industry-driven Bachelor of Applied Science (BAS) degree in Computer Network Architecture (CNA). This degree, presently offered at Renton Technical College (RTC), provides the education required for advanced careers in Information Technology (IT).

The project had three primary goals:

  1. To address the talent gap of bachelor-level educated individuals in the computer network field.
  2. To provide individuals with the knowledge, skills and abilities (KSAs) needed to meet industry-demand for careers in the computer network field.
  3. To attract more high school students around the Puget Sound area into RTC Computer Networking (CNT, BAS CNA) programs.

This grant provided the initial funds to hire necessary staff and faculty, and build out the program without risk to the college. Staffing included a full time, tenure track lead faculty position that also served as the Principal Investigtor (PI) for the grant, as well as a Co-PI who was the Dean of the programs. Staffing also included a part time BAS Program Manager/Grant Manager and a part time BAS Program Coordinator. 

The project team established a Business Industry Leadership Team (BILT) by securing letters of support from five major IT companies in the area. The BILT provided regular feedback and advising on the program's planned curriculum. Meetings were held quarterly to ensure that program content and hands-on activities and equipment used were keeping pace with industry trends. 

Due to a lag in the processing of accreditation paperwork, the BAS CNA program's official launch was delayed 6 months past the target date. Despite this setback, the program has grown to 109% capacity within 12 months. The project attracted more women, veterans and underserved populations into the computer networking programs and careers. The programs current demographics include 52% students of color, 32% with a disability, and 80% on need-based aid. As of October 2019, applications received for the third cohort of students, to begin Spring 2020, is already 50% full. The project team is currently exploring the opportunity for adding an additional entry point for the program, beginning Fall 2020.

The project endured significant challenges. Staff turnover, both within the project and beyond, occurred throughout the project. Investigators struggled to keep positions created as part of the grant, such as the Program Coordinator, filled. The BILT, the program's primary connection to industry, disbanded as all members retired or changed jobs. Constant innovation in IT required faculty to adjust curriculum regularly to stay relevant. Employed students wrestled to balance work and school, as overtime and on-call rotations impacted their performance.

The project succeeded in launching the first bachelor's of applied science in computer network architecture in Washington state. Project staff disseminate knowledge by assisting other community colleges to design applied bachelor's programs in technology. The program is expected to thrive for the forseeable future. 


Last Modified: 10/31/2019
Modified by: William Sanderson
